segments.text: Hello and welcome to Veterans of the Valley.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I'm Tom Turbeville.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Some call it the Forgotten War, but Norman Beale of rural Bradstess County has not forgotten a thing about his 2nd Battalion, 5th Marines, assault on the Korean coast in 1950.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Nor has he forgotten the horror and the cold of that winter, scaling the cliffs at the beaches at Incheon.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: The card game that he lost that kept him in Korea to fight even longer.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: The Korean War cost 54,000 American lives and another 8,000 were missing.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Norman Beale counts himself very lucky to have survived to tell his story of service.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Please welcome Norman Beale of Edge to Veterans of the Valley.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Mr. Beale, it's an honor to have you on Veterans of the Valley and thank you first for your service.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You were a local kid all the way.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You grew up in Bryan.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You graduated from Allen Academy in 1948.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: and want to move right along because you joined the Marine Corps soon after you graduated from high school in 1948.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Sort of take us from there and your service in the Marine Corps and sort of how that got you overseas to Korea.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Well, I was overseas in other places also for a couple of years and came back to the States and a few months later we had to turn around and go back.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: But we didn't, and the Marine Corps at that time in 1948 only had about 75,000 Marines.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: So they had to scrape all over the world to get more Marines to develop a brigade.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: General MacArthur was calling for Marines
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: early and all we could gather up was one brigade and each battalion was missing one company.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And the companies that we did have only had two platoons.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: So that was... Right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: This was a time that the military had really changed because it was after World War II and the military was kind of scaling down at that time.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Very much so.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: You talked about how the military had changed during this time between World War II and before the Korean War broke out.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Yeah, after World War II, all future wars were going to be push-button.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And so the Air Force decided they didn't need too many Army personnel, didn't even need the Marines, but the Navy, they wanted to keep the Navy.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Right, right, right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You had spent a long time...
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: on a boat.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I know you'd gone out to the Marianas Islands in the West Pacific for your training and you came home, said you'd never get on a boat again, but that was wrong because Korean War broke out and you were headed to Korea.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I didn't want to get in on any more stinking ships.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: You talk highly about the training that you got because you said that a lot of the NCOs and the officers were World War II veterans who were certainly
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: a war experience themselves.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So you did get some good training from these folks.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Yes, and just the Marine Corps trains all the time.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: I finally got back to the States and I got out of the Fleet Marine Force and was put in a company that didn't go in the field.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: So our new colonel decided we were getting soft
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And after I was there about three weeks, we were put in the field again.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And I learned how to dig foxholes again.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And you would need that later on, obviously.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: 2nd Battalion, 5th Marines.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: This is one of the oldest outfits dating back to World War I. As a matter of fact, I looked up, it was the German soldiers that actually gave them the nickname the Devil Dogs because they were so tough fighting in World War I in 1918.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Bellow Wood.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: That's right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: That's right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So this was a part of the outfit that you were in.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You left San Diego August of 1950 and thought you were going to
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: stop over in Japan, but you went straight to the coast of Korea to Pusan.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Talk about that.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: There was not much of South Korea left.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: That's why we didn't stop.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And when we got to Pusan, Korea,
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Our general was down on the dock, and he wanted to know if Colonel Murray had gotten his message.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And Murray called down and said, no, sir.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And he said, well, you get off the ship now, and let's move on to the front.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And that was his message that we didn't get.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: But fortunately, we spent that whole night unloading the ship.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And early the next morning, we moved forward.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: So you didn't stick around long.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You were headed to the front.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Talk about that.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Talk about your first venture into combat, heading towards North Korea.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: What you recall about that?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Because you're still a young kid.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I mean, you're a young kid from the country.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And it was quite a...
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Quite a change in your life, obviously.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We were down in South Korea, and like I say, we were pushed into combat right away on August the 7th.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: We attacked, and that was the same date that the offensive action in World War II, August the 7th at Guadalcanal, the 1st Marine Division, which the 5th Marines was part of.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And we, after a few days, we had pushed the North Koreans back 30 miles, 30-plus miles.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And the very next day or two, we were called back.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Down south, they could not protect our sides.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And we then were put in what we call the fire brigade.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: We'd move from one spot to another, trying to hold the North Koreans back.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And we had two major battles on the Nak-tong River.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: The first Nagtong, we pushed them back over the river, and we all went down and rested two days or three days.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And we were called back up because we had lost, or the military had lost, the Nagtong front again.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: It was called the Nagtong Bulge, the 6th North Korean People's Army.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Very sophisticated.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: They had come from...
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: sold the capital all the way down to this little area down in Pusan we call it the Pusan Perimeter and they had not hit anything but they found a new breed of cat
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: down there right and so you go ahead then we were pulled off the night tone and all of a sudden we went down to Seoul Pusan right and we got on board ship and we started we thought maybe we'd get to go back to Japan for our duty
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Because you'd done such a good job.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Because we'd done such a good job.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Yeah, but?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I looked out one morning and there were ships in every direction.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And then they come on the intercom and they told us that we had been selected.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: to hit the North Koreans right in the throat.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: We were going to make an Incheon landing at Seoul.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Seoul was about 30-something miles from Incheon.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: But when we got to Incheon, all the Navy were bombarding Incheon, poor people.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And our planes were coming over and strafing and bombing.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Didn't see how anybody could live.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Right, right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Amigo.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Oh, Amigo, there we go.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I was close.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Yes, to the mainland.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Right, right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Yes, oh yes.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: up 30, the tide, 30 feet, and then it would drop.

segments.text: And after it dropped, there was just a huge mudflat out there, and our ships were in the mud, still shooting.
